Removed chunking as done in #1924.
I don't see a reason to add tests here, I would if it was straight forward but its not - I'd have to open ugly APIs and mock some of the parameters and eventually this is a Spark FlatMapFunction so the natural way to test it is as part of a Spark pipeline. ROS should do, and since order is not required any more, I think current tests are enough.

Ok @dhalperi I rebased as you proposed, tell me if it is ok now. I will create a new PR for the OPs changes. Notice that the missing changes are the one who bring the performance improvementop

We already do `Clean after checkout`, which includes the following description:
"This ensures that the workspace is in the same state as if you cloned and checked out in a brand-new empty directory, and ensures that your build is not affected by the files generated by the previous build."

Then, there's `Wipe out repository & force clone`, which includes the following description:
"Delete the contents of the workspace before building, ensuring a fully fresh workspace."

Then, there's [Workspace Cleanup Plugin](https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/Workspace+Cleanup+Plugin).

The description for `Prune stale remote-tracking branches` is:
"Run "git remote prune" for each remote, to prune obsolete local branches."

All these things try to make the build more hermetic. I have more confidence in `Wipe out` or `Workspace Cleanup` than `clean` + `prune`. Seems more hermetic.

Won't object either way. LGTM for this PR. LGTM for removal of `clean` and `prune` in favor of `wipe out`.
R: @dhalperi @bjchambers (either)

+1 that it makes mapping much, much nicer.
+1 that is used by several other Apache projects.

-1 that makes email addresses easy to collect. (Sure, they are already publicly available, but there's a meaningful extra effort to scrape them from git, which makes it not worth the effort for others.)
-1 on the administrative burden to keep it useful.

The benefit is limited to command-line usage of git; GitHub has a separate mapping database.

Also, other cases seem to look slightly different:
* https://github.com/apache/climate/blob/master/.mailmap
* https://github.com/apache/incubator-edgent/blob/master/.mailmap
* https://github.com/apache/couchdb/blob/master/.mailmap

Overall, I think we can go either way. Personally, I think cons outweigh the benefits, so I'm slightly opposed, but won't object if others want to pursue this. If you'd like to proceed, please wait for at least a few named individuals are fine being listed here.

The benefit is actually not just command-line `git` itself but other mature tools that use the git history. GitHub is a reasonable exception, since they have their own protocol for email claiming.

Anyhow I look at the history far more often through `git` than through GitHub, especially in interesting cases. So, personally, it is already nice even if that is the only benefit. Probably I am not the only one.

I considered your cons before putting this together, but have these thoughts:

 - Actually every email address here is already present in the git log. Anyone writing a scraper will go there first, since it is more common. I deliberately have not added any information. If anything, it will actually make some scrapers get fewer emails :-). I will seek approvals from people listed though. 
 - The administrative burden is a good thing to think of, but I propose to not centrally administer the list, thus making the burden zero. I am offering this initial list as a volunteer effort on my part. After that, it can just be as folks desire. You'll also notice that a lot of the bad names are just from tool-generated history, so the burden is much lower going forwards. (more contributors, but fewer needed in this file)
 - As for the format, there are a few different formats and you can choose them on a line-by-line basis. I chose one that seemed very simple. I've checked it out and didn't see obvious issues, but it is my first attempt at a `.mailmap`.

So in summary in my opinion we can easily choose for the cons to measure zero, but also the pros are not very important. Just some nice polish.
Based on mailing list discussion and comments here, I think this is g2g. Anyone care to give a formal LGTM?

Ack on other comments; one comment however.

> Anyone writing a scraper will go there first, since it is more common.

Indeed, as we both commented, this is already public information in "git log". However, I wanted to point out web crawling way of scrapping things. Before this PR, web crawler probably wouldn't get it; after it, it will. This is the most common. However, an argument against this is: ~sooner or later it will leak somewhere else, not worth trying to prevent it.

Again, I'm (very) slightly against, but if you like it, LGTM.
